description: An introduction to the study of culture and human institutions, how they change, and their role in both literate and nonliterate societies.
name: INTRO TO CULT ANTH

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to the study of culture and human institutions, how they change, and their role in both literate and non-literate societies. It may be counted as a distributional course in Society. 

Students commented that this course was “interesting,” “fun,” and motivated students to think outside the box. While most students felt that the lectures and course material were stimulating and enjoyable, some felt that the readings were “too complex for an introductory class.” Overall, students found the course to be a positive experience and several commented that it made them want to declare a major or minor in Anthropology. 

Students described Professor Urban as, “very engaging,” and “enthusiastic about what he does.” Generally, students commented that Professor Urban’s teaching style made the class interesting. 

While many students thought the readings for the course “tie into lecture material pretty well,” they also called them, “very dense,” and “quite challenging.” However, students described the projects assigned for the course as, “interesting and very manageable.” Students agreed that the class was better suited for freshmen than upperclassmen.
